reviewText:
I wanted to like this game.  Really I did.  I mean, it's basically Puzzle Quest, and I LOVE puzzle quest.  For a free game, there is a lot of content to it, from quests, to items, challenges, troops for your party, and so on.  I should love this game.

Then I ran out of coins, and could no longer play the game.

To elaborate, at the start of the game, you're given a few hundred coins.  These aren't used to buy better equipment or level up your soldiers, (as far as I am aware, I may just not have gotten that far yet) they're the currency that lets you play the game at all.
Yes, your kingdom generates a certain number of coins per hour I believe (up to 500 per day max to start) and quests earn you a meager amount, (most I've gotten so far was 9) but every single challenge and quest takes about 50 coins to play.

The cash shop I don't mind.  It's a free game, and they need to make money to stay in business.  I understand that part.
But I will never understand game mechanics that actually prevent you from playing the game.  Any desire I might have for potentially spending money on the shinies is killed by the fact that I just plain can't play the game until a set period of time passes.
voteText: 187 of 234 people (80%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
UPDATE March 2016
The game is what is and anyone that thinks it looks interesting should give it a go. The dev has added a lot of new mechanics and content and I feel it's certainly improved the game overall. It's truly free to play now (you don't need to manufacture gold while battling to enter more battles after you run out of your kingdom bonuses and daily gold like it used to be, which is only an issue at the start) and it's also available on android, ios and the consoles so if you end up liking it you got a lot of different ways to play it.

It's a total grindfest and you need to get into a good guild if you want to make any kind of progress but overall if you like the gameplay and the acquiring of stuff and leveling it up... game delivers.

Original flip floppy mess of reviewlike substance

If you really liked puzzle quest than this game can be enjoyable provided you don't feel lured into going crazy with the PTW dynamics of the game that make a difference with how fast you progress and how strong you get relative to other players.

If you just PvE at your own pace though and non compulsively it's alright. Stay away if you can't since it's designed to drain your wallet if you let it so with that in mind I can't really recommend it.

EDIT1: It takes a while before you can really afford it but the arena mode is where it's at for free to play players. I got so much stuff out of that mode that it really helped me out with all the rest (as in improving my deck to be more competitive with the more difficult challenges and the 'fake' PvP).

I definitely recommend this to puzzle quest fans that are patient enough to get this to work without spending much if any money.

EDIT2: I played and enjoyed this game for over 100 hours (I do idle but still). I can't in my right mind not recommend the game. The game is perfectly playable for free or you can spend some money during sales to speed up your progress and get a good armor.

Basically if you play smart, you'll be fine as FTP and get a very enjoyable experience if this is your kind of game (ergo puzzle/rpg/strategy hybrid). Just check Tacet's guide for a lot of good pointers and you'll be a gem master... someday.

EDIT3: Back to negative. This game is just too much of a mind screw for those that are susceptible to that to recommend, only try it if you can handle playing and enjoying the game at your own pace and are comfortable now having to HAVE everything that there's to get in the game. I've only spent 2 bucks on the game myself and that's all it's ever going to get from me.

EDIT4: Blah... its basically a lot of fun if you like match 3 and trying out different combinations of troops and the like even with the paywall stuff but if you are sufficiently advanced to belong to a good guild... you can get everything eventually. All depends on the type of gamer you are. No need to go overboard on the spending for the game to be sure with a little discipline.

reviewText:
I don't even know where to start.

If I ever wanted to make someone hate the original Puzzle Quest, this would be the game I'd make, I guess.

As a lot of people already mentioned here, one of the most obvious and frustrating gripe with the game is the enemy AI. The game does not revolve around the player trying to make good matches. It revolves around the player trying to avoid creating matches for the AI. But resistance is futile, if you don't create matches for the enemy, the board will make sure to create it for you from outside of the table. You think you made a good skull match? Hah! Think again, because you just created two other for the opponent. It really downplays any kind of strategy.

Then there is the progression system".

Your currencies are gold

Besides the fact that the reward is half as much as you have to pay to fight a battle, this game has the
worst.
cheating.
AI.
EVER.

The AI always gets the extra turns, always gets the skulls, always gets a great combination of gems and/ or skulls just as it's about to lose and turns the tide of the battle. Always.

Until then it's recommended, give it a try, but at the same time, no I don't recommend it. It will only ♥♥♥♥ you off.

reviewText: When first I started playing this game, it was amazing: a casual game with the feel of a hardcore RPG.  Collect troops like pokemon, build them up and find the best combinations to secure victory.  It eased me into PVP without my even knowing it, and there the game truly shined.  Your level didn't matter so much as your strategy and your team building; a low level character could beat a much higher level one if he kept his head.  Best of all, everything that could be purchased could also be found in game with persistance.\n\nSo why the negative review?  Well, each update to the game has taken a little something away.  The gameplay is still casual, but the team building has gotten very complex.  Players with a lot of in game resources (read that either play obssesively or payed out for them") now have a massive advantage over those that don't.  Also

reviewText:
I really enjoy playing this game. I like the gameplay and the idea of matching the different colored gems to attack your opponent and gaining mana to use special effects. The graphics are nice and the game is pleasant to look at. It’s easy to lose track of time while playing all the quests – if you have the coins to do them.

It’s got many nice features, but I do have some suggestions for it. Most of these are small changes or additions I’d like to see, but there are a couple of issues I’ll be addressing as well. I feel bad about giving this game a negative review (because it is a good game), but there is an issue that needs to be fixed before I can recommend this game.

There isn’t too much variety on how your character appears – 6 different races and your gender. So there are really only 12 different appearances your character can have, not including the two types of free armor and (the other ones you have to pay real money for). I’d like to see more variety in customizing your character.

The gem hints" can be useful

reviewText:
I really want to like this game.

It's not a bad game at all.  The basic gameplay is fine (essentially playing Bejeweled against an opponent on the same board), although the luck factor is extremely high--frustratingly so from my perspective.

The combat system adds the extra element of a player's party.  In theory, it adds a nice feature to the game; it rewards tactical and strategic thinking, and gives the player incentive to build a party.  But that just makes the high luck factor all that much more frustrating, from my perspective--I hate having the right team, and making the right play, but losing because the skyfall set my opponent up for an insanely good string.

Also, the monster skills could use a balance pass or two, but that's a fairly minor complaint.  Nothing feels broken--it's just odd that the minions of a boss are sometimes more powerful than the boss itself, or that a monster might have a skill that's just flat-out better than a similar skill held by a monster of similar rarity and gem color.

The artwork is fine, in a cartoony sort of way.  The plots (each kingdom you purchase has its own) are funny and absurdist, which I appreciated.  The music isn't great, but isn't bad.

The UI and new player tutorials are pretty bad--hopefuly they get fixed.   For example:  you can save different party compositions, but you can't alter those party compositions without starting a battle.  Those party compositions are heavily dependent on which weapon your player is using--but you have to change weapons from the main map screen.  The game is full of menus, challenges, side quests, and features, none of which are properly explained.  Again, fixable, but frustrating.

In any case, if they fix the tutorial and UI, and give the game a balance patch, I would probably change my review to recomend"--if you are really into match-games with a bit of strategic thinking.  But even then
date: there are better games out there than this one."

reviewText:
This puzzle game looks good and the gameplay is interesting and fun. It is a comination of CCG and bejeweld. Each card has its own gems that will power its unique aility.
You always have to keep in mind that your opponent is using the same board, so you can win by getting good combinations for yourself, but can also win by making sure your opponent never gets an opportunity to make good combinations.
In the beginning the battles are too easy, but they get more challenging later on.

However after an hour or 2 you run out of gold in the game. Gold is used to play, and therefore have to pay real life money to play. A game costs 50 gold, and with 2€ you can buy 1000 gold. If the games take about as long as they did at the start, this means you have to pay 1€ per hour to play the game. This is way too expensive for such a basic game. If they had an other paying model, like paying 20€ and play forever, I would strongly suggest to get this game. With the super overpriced paying model the game uses however, I suggest to stay far away from it.

reviewText: One of the greatest hoaxes on Steam, gives you enough currency to deceive you into thinking it is actually free to play (at any given time 'till the end of the century or Steam) and then drops the punchline - the amount of gold you need to progress further increases exponentially! Now, I'm talking about geometric-progression-type of increase, with each new kingdom price (yes, you need to actually BUY a kingdom to do quests in it) going up by 250 gold (I've played until there was a 1.000 gold fee to progress further.) Also, the PvP is not an actual, live matchmaking system but a matchmaking with someone's roster where the cheating, unmistakable A.I gets luck rolls with OP cards (like that worms that burrows itself, damages the last unit in your roster for 6 points, then creates a ♥♥♥♥-load of brown gems and gets extra turns and the ability to do that on the next turn as well.)\n\nAll in all, an unbalanced, pitiful excuse from people that developed REAL gems like Puzzle Quest 1 and 2. They stooped so low you may as well refer to them as Cash-grab + Infinity" instead of Infinity + 2..."

reviewText:
One of the most unforgiving games. When a developer has to post a sticky (over 200 posts) about it's own game not cheating, you know it's bad. Usually posts about cheating from developers revolve around player misconduct, but not this game. There's zero player vs player. Their idea of making it difficult is giving itself advantages moves that occur off the board or there is literally no moves left except for a move that would be bad for you. Even if the computer has one or two colors to gain mana and you cleared the board of it, 9 times out of 10 it will get it from cascades. It will make moves that don't help itself and suddenly turns into a chain or extra turn.

If that doesn't drive you to either quit or pay money, they raised the cost to level your cards and they increase their level cap. The only people to truely benefit from that is the developers because now that means they can prolong the time it would take to max everything out. It didn't help the players certainly not the new players who now have a harder time to catch up to everyone. This brings me to their pseudo pvp. The only thing that your opponent controls is the setup, but you're essentially still playing PVE. They also make the match ups completely lopsided, so new players will have to deal with veteran players who have the advantage of already having a max team. Their latest attempt in adding content is a draft game, which has been out for over a month and a half now, Is just the worst part of this game. In addition to the computer being rediculous, the cards you picked from the draft may disappear and be replaced with cards that you didn't choose. This is a known issue since it's introduction that the developers have made no compensation or actions to fix their programming. They also rarely stay up to date with their steam players, so expect your posts to be forgotten and have to repost it like spam.

If you want to play this game, then don't spend money. Let the developers bleed out more till they understand that when profits become more important than the players the game will not live long, and the community should not condone it with fundings. Just like Transformers, it is our duty as the consumer to not support their choices. Great games do not drive into a corner to earn your money. Great games get support from players because we want the game to have longevity.

reviewText:
This would be a good game if it weren't for the shameless attempt to coax you into microtransactions. Your game is held ransom until you pay up or you wait a day.

Playing the game costs gold pieces. They give you a lot up front, but then the cost of playing a match (x, where x >=50gp) begins to outweigh the reward for winning a match (<x).

You accumulate gold daily, but you can pay real money for game currency which you then use to SIMPLY PLAY THE GAME.

reviewText: This game is just plain fun. It's a FTP from the makers of puzzle quest and its DNA shines bright. reviewText:
It's not even Pay 2 Win, it's Pay 2 Keep Up with the AI,

Without any ability to grind at lower difficulties or replay missions/stages, the AI-controlled opponents quickly outclass you and it just becomes an ever-increasing upwards battle that makes each match longer and longer and more difficult to win and, ultimately, less fun.

While I can appreciate difficult opponents, there is no satisfaction when it comes in beating one in this game because of the way it is designed. The next opponent will be just as, if not moreso difficult as it becomes sheer tedium to lose over and over until you happen to land a particularly lucky sequence. Relying on luck rather than skill/strategy is a pointless and unrewarding venture.

Like others have said before me, to play this game without paying for it, you must spend inordinate amounts of time not-playing" it
date: instead logging in daily to collect your gold bonuses and saving up to buy things that may or may not make you competitive. This game actually rewards you for not playing it! So
recommended:
how do you win a game like that? By not installing it in the first place.

tl;dr: Fun for the first hour or two. Avoid the rest.

Edit: lol and it doesn't even have Steam Cloud!"

reviewText:
I have to say that some of the negative reviews do seem a bit harsh.

Firstly, you can play the game without paying anything  if you are a reasonable player at matching games. It does cost 50-60 gold to battle but you can earn  a basic return of 25+ gold back each fight, over 100 gold if its PVP plus 4-5 gold everytime you get 4 or 5 in a row. I can easily break even or make a profit in the majority of fights.

The game matches PVP players which I have found to be very reasonable and well balanced.

Secondly, if you complete all of a cities quests you win that cities hero card so it is possible to build a team of 4 good monsters/heroes. I think it took me about 5 days to gain the first city hero card without paying anything. I have no doubt as you progress the top players will pay to play but you can still have a really good experience without doing so if you really want.

After about 6 days of playing i bought some keys and the return was very good compared to other games I have played. I did get several high quality cards.

No doubt the guild system requires a lot more work but again you can play without a guild quite easily.

So give it a go its a really good game and it is free to play  :)

reviewText:
It was a fun game for a while, but every update lately has made major changes to the game and each change pushes the game further and further into a sleazy P2W microtransaction based RNG game.

For instance, you used to be able to get three troops guaranteed with every iron key and now with the latest update each iron key gets you one random thing that may or may not be a troop, but is more likely some new 'upgrade' item that just got introduced. You will need about 40 of these little doohickeys to actually do ONE upgrade for one unit, and each unit has multiple upgrades to it..  Yay for progress?

Unfortunately I have to recommend that people stay away, there are better match 3 games out there that are less driven to push microtransactions.  While I liked the game overall and I love the puzzle quest games, the continuining path of pushing microtransactions harder and harder with each patch made me stop playing.  After playing this and some of their other titles, it almost feels like the original puzzle quest was just a sheer stroke of luck.
voteText: 16 of 23 people (70%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Ehhh, game is a mediocre match 3 game.  Not the worst ofthem, but there are many others I enjoyed more.

Basically the issues are;
While the cascade chains tend to be rarer, the falls are heavily in favor of the AI, it will almost always get something to make your life miserable.

It is built backwards from what a game like this should be.  It is a grind for the beginning player.  A terrible terrible grind.
Everything you want to do uses gold, But every win you get returns a lower quantity of gold than you spent to perform the action, and every lose is pretty much a 100% loss - The only exception is the quasi-pvp matches, where you can get slightly better than double the returns on your investment... until you reach a mid-rank pvp area when the game starts heavily cheating and you are losing as often as you win, so this is where the grind comes in... trying to make enough gold together to expand into a reasonable roster, while trying to overcome the constant hemorrhaging of gold.
The backwardsnes of the game is that the systems in place make it so that the longer you play and and take advantage of the world mechanics in place, and get your team to a more competetive level, the easier, and more money money you make, but since there are no real high-level gold expenditures, there reaches a point where money is unimportant and you don't care about it anymore.

If the game found more a middle ground where the early game didn't feel like death, I'd probably recommend trying it out if Match-3 is your thing.  As it stands, I find it an exercise in masochism that I am not interested in.

reviewText:
I obtained access to this game as free download during the steam sale and it may not be feree to play any more.

If you played the original gem quest this game is in the same vein.

It is a gem matching game with a twist of having skull gems to damage your opponent.

The single player campaign game consists to quests and you have to pay in game gold pieces to get the next quest but these are easy to earn and I have not spent a cent of real cash yet to play the game. Thera are also many upgrades and levelling that are available to Free players. P2W is possible and I have run into more that one low level player that kicked my ♥♥♥, but that could also be down to luck of the draw.

At the moment PvP seems to be virtual in that you battle other players teams without the player input. However the AI never misses an advantage on behalf of the opponent.

I love gem matching games and the price is fantastic if you get it for free.

Additional comment: One bug I have found that is annoying is if the internet goes down or has a dodgy connection then you get stuck in a loop as the game tries to recconnect. The only escape I have been able to do is to use Task manager to close down the game.

reviewText:
Gems of War is a CCG Match-3 Puzzle RPG. Every one of these elements has a pivotal stake in the gameplay, so if any of these elements are considered undesirable to you, the game could begin to feel like a slog at certain points.

Cross-Platform between PC/Mobile, while the Xbox/Playstation versions are purely independent and are unable to connect across platforms. Keep this in mind when choosing which platform to play on. (Certain features are exclusive to Xbox and Playstation, while other features might be missing.)

Gems of War has come a long way from when I first started. This is a bit of a running theme with how active patches are in the game, completely reworking some mechanics every couple or few months. Adaptability is very important to have in this case. If you don't like change, whether in your team setup, new features, or reworked mechanics, I highly recommend you against playing this game.

But even among all the differences between when I first started and now, a few things have always remained the same. The core gameplay, the weekly excitement, and the amazing developers.

Core GameplayAs mentioned in the beginning of this review, GoW has 3 very consistent points to stand on.

Collectible Card Game  - If you've ever played a CCG online game, you'll no right off the bat that trading is a no go. There's no clear plans of this changing anytime soon either. So if you're desperate to get that one troop card you really want, you'll have to leave your fate in the hands of the RNG.

Match-3 Puzzle - Power up your troop's spells by collecting on board colored gems. You can match skulls instead to inflict attack damage. These are both very important to your success in winning a match. Troops spells often offer board control to manipulate the playing field to your advantage, or possibly screw yourself over. 4+ matches also offer an extra turn, meaning another free match before the opponent gets to play, so thinking out your moves and observing the board carefully are important.

Role-playing Game - Leveling, Ascension, and Traits are all key aspects in powering-up your troops to better handle opponents. Obviously some troops will outshine others, some times you'll need to use another team to handle the situation better than your primary one. There's many ways to learn how to build your teams, but the best one is the Arena, an important minigame that'll teach you team synergy and introduce you to all sorts of spells.

Weekly ExcitementWeekly events are what they're known as, and are a fun way to keep you interested in playing. Whether it's a new troop or Hero weapon, not a week's gone by since I began playing that there wasn't something to look forward to.

Some months a new kingdom is introduced, and other months we've got a whole new patch to explore! The amount of content provided so frequently is mind-boggling sometimes, and keeps my interest firmly gripped for whatever may come next.

The DevelopersYou honestly won't see them much around the Steam community or in the AppStore, but if you give their online forums[community.gemsofwar.com] a chance, you'll quickly realize how much attention they pay to player feedback. They keep active and enjoy chatting with the community, even when things get rather heated.

Support will also quickly look into and resolve issues as soon as possible, they've even offered apology gifts to compensate the delay on occasion.

Negative Points?Some people have expressed concern or a hatred for certain aspects of the game, so I'll be addressing these issues here so you can know to avoid the game if they aren't to your liking.

F2P or P2W? - The game is most assuredly Free 2 Play. The most that money will reward you is Pay 2 Progress faster. I, myself, have not spent even a dime on the game. This isn't out of disrespect for the devs or because of a lack of thanks for an (imo) amazing game, but to help prove a point that everything in this game can be achieved without spending any money whatsoever.

Cheating AI? - The game has 50-100% random board drops. This is both a good and bad thing, as you can get massive cascades and possibly never lose a turn to the opponent (with decent board control), but the flipside to this is that the opponent has the same possible luck, meaning some matches can feel lost without any skill involved. This is rare, being normally a 1/10 chance you'll lose this way, but the better you improve your builds and plan out your matches, the less likely this is to occur. Just know that randomness is a factor.

Too Many Resources? - I won't sugar coat it. There's a lot to take in as the games progressed over this time. Gold, Souls, Gems, Keys, Glory, Maps, Traitstones. All of it's important, but the positive to this is how much there is to do! And you can never get stuck, there's always someway to recoup your losses or an alternate route of progression, but practice and learning are factors that never fade.
VerdictSo is this game for you? If the idea of a Match-3 RPG with countless hours of play (700+ hours now and not even halfway done) sounds interesting to you, definitely give it a shot.

reviewText: The table is tilted, the game is rigged. As others have mentioned the game makes sure AI gets an advantage with numerous extra turns. Enemy power level also scales up so fast you're almost required to spend money to buy upgrades. If you own Puzzle Quest, play that instead.\n\nEdit: I forgot to mention that some elements of the game's art, such as the victory screen and card design seem somewhat familiar. And the way you open a chest with cards in it is by dragging a key to it, flipping the cards over by clicking on them, and the game announcing rare cards. All this bears a striking resemblance to a certain card game about stones of the hearth.
voteText: 9 of 11 people (82%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Have you ever watched Wipe-Out? Ever noticed how those obstacles seem to be more accurate or faster depending on the contestant? Well say 'hello' to the video game equivalent! You're never really playing a 'game' when you're playing Gems of War. You are simply participating in the most blatant 'skinner-box'-ing I've ever seen.

At first glance the game is rather appealing. 'Match-three'-style gameplay with collectable card-based units that have differing levels of health and armor, along with various special abilities. Abilities which are charged by clearing colors corresponding to that unit. A lot of fun and hints at a strategic depth that could really keep you searching for that perfect member for your team!

Unfortunately there is a hidden player in every game: The skinner-box.

See, you're supposed to win some games and lose others. That keeps you motivated, interested and encourages you to monetize by buying items for real money. The game is pretty set on this so you'll see a lot of strange things start to happen. Maybe the computer seems to be smarter during this round. Maybe the computer quite blatantly holds back on the final blow. Maybe the computer (or you) is particularly lucky in what pieces drop from the top. It isn't very obvious at first, but the longer you play the more blatant it becomes. At my current level of skill it's like a fork in the eye. My opponent almost never lands a blow unless it's with pieces that dropped down after my turn. I've seen the computer go on streaks of up to 6 moves (you get more moves if you combine 4 or more pieces at once), while I myself have never gotten higher than three. I've seen four attack blocks come down from the top, clearing themselves and allowing my AI opponent to go again. I've seen the game basically go as far as it possibly can to stop me from winning. Strangely, I've seen it do the same to let me win. I've been a turn away from defeat, only to 'luckily' receive the blocks I needed and enough of them to get another turn, followed by 'luckily' getting attack blocks in just the right place to be able to defeat my enemy.


And there we come to the crux of the issue. This is a failed game. It doesn't reward skill. It doesn't punish failure. It simply is. You could sit your four-year-old in front of it, and he'd do decently with the skinner-box looking over him, or you could put the grand-champion matcher and... he'd do decently.


So stay away from this game. There are plenty others that do what it does, only better.

reviewText:
Too many bugs to be out of beta:
1: An entire battle can be lost from a single move, Example:
I destroy 3/4 of the enemies creatures, he then combines for an extra turn, then gets another extra turn and attack, then another attack with extra turn, then he uses his ability to destroy my last unit.
2: Abilities can easily be wasted, Example:
My alchemist can turn any colour into yellow, so i click him, click cast AND IT INSTANTLY CHANGES WHATEVER GEM IS BEHIND THE CAST BUTTON.
3: Gold is far too expensive to attract any new players, Example:
i first start the game, and it costs more gold to do quests then i get from completing them, meaning i have to save my gold for quests, i have to save my gold ALSO for towns, i have to save my gold ALSO for more cards.
EXTRA: Gold can only ever be gained by going offline and waiting... any game that requires you NOT to play to progress has a fundamental flaw.

All in all i can say this game shouldn't of left beta yet, these are some serious bugs.

reviewText:
It is a match-2, RPG, free where spending money dose not give you an advantage.

It takes a while to build up troops and collect souls to level them up to make a team. Don't need a perfect team or even a fully leveled troops. While luck is always a small part, limiting possible unlucky drops is key to winning against a tough team.

Join an active guild and it will not take long to build up different troops, guilds are there mostly for chat board and tasks that yields keys and gems. But why read this? It is a free game and it gets funner the longer you play.

reviewText: Warning to everyone who plays this game. Unless you unlck more kingdoms you cannot play the 2 minigames in this game.\nI lovethis game. My fovorite thing to do is use tyri's spell to get maps. These maps are used to play one of the minigames. The other game requires 1000 gold. That minigame is called arena. 10/10 would map again. You can ask the developers anything and if you are having technical difficulties staff can sometimes fix it in minutes.

reviewText:
I wanted to like this game so much.

I was a HUGE fan of puzzle quest, and have bought most of the solo games in the series over the years from that developer.  So when I saw this I thought it was a no brainer.  But after about an hour and a half in the game I'm really crushed by what I've witnessed.

1. Always connected means that if your internet drops, or their servers lag, or a mouse farts in china.... you drop connection.  Now you might be saying But Rhev
date: I have a good connection!"  Yeah
recommended: you know what?  So do I
hoursPlayed: normally.  But in about an hour and a half I lost connection three different times.  Once it didn't matter
voteText: but the other two times it was at the end of a match
helpfulPercent:
when I'd won.  Do you know what happens then?  When you reconnect the game treats it as if you hadn't played that match.

THIS IS UNACCEPTABLE.

That alone would give it a do not play ranking.  But....

2. the microtransactions;  Oh god the microtransactions.  It's full on facebook mode here follks.  PAY PAY PAY!   BEST VALUE!  BOOST YOUR GAME!   LIMITED TIME!

I understand that a game that's free to play needs to monitize
votesHelpful: and I don't fault them for it.  But there's a way to do it that's obnoxious (like this game does) and a way that's subtle
votesTotal: and makes you feel all right about either choosing to support them with some cash
votesFunny: or not spending a dime ever.\n\nYou want to know what's good about this game?  There are quite a bit of good aspects mind you
commentsCount:
but you can go read any of the other positive reviews.  I just wanted to give my thoughts on the problems with this game.

FIX THE LAG.


EDIT -
Played it again.... the game freezes up during a certain battle.  Three times now I've tried to complete a quest battle and it always locks up around the same time when I use one of my troop's abilities.

Uninstalling now."

reviewText:
Meh.

The game isn't bad, and I mean, if you're interested in gem matching Cwazy Cupcakes style play, well, you could do worse.

That said, this game trys to pass itself as stategy by adding troops and whatnot, but it doesn't feel like stategy at all. It feels like sheer luck if you win or lose.

Moreso even than other Puzzle Quest Games.

Character leveling is in the game, but there isn't really much choice to it, or any feeling that the choices you do make really matter.

And, I know it likely sounds like sour grapes, but it totally feels like the game is cheating. It will take the obvious four block break, or the skulls that do damage most of the time. Occationally though, the AI will ignore these to go for some basic three block break, which then causes a series of awesome combos to fall from off screen.

I'm not saying that the game is cheating when this happens, but it sure feels that way.

Whichever. If you like breaking blocks, give it a go. I'm going back to Marvel Puzzle Quest for my personal yelling at the screen game though.

reviewText:
While this game is free to pay it does want you to make purchases in order to have any kind of advantage -and keep playing. It feels far to much like one of those free facebook games like Candy Crush Saga. However, there is the elements of card collecting and a little turn-based RPG thrown in. It's not a bad game, don't get me wrong. But little annoyances here and there can really get to you. Like figuring out that you have to pay with in game currency in order to do a quest but suddenly can't afford it because you've spent it all doing quests in the first place! You don't even make back in rewards what you spent to do the quest either.
Also, while the AI doesn't cheat there is really something funky going on with it. This is quite obvious and I'm not the only one to notice this. While I'm not up for the challenge I do get very p-ed off when I am able to get a couple mana surges in a row and then on my opponent's turn he is able to drop down 'randomly' five mana surges and a couple attacks while he's at it. This has happened on more than one occasion and if I have to I will record it.
On the other hand, the AI will rarely be as dumb as a board. When this happens it's quite fun to watch. As such, I recommend playing with game hints off as this really does you little good and you'll have a better chance of winning without it. Once your eyes adjust to the game board and the patterning you'll be more on level ground. That, and A LOT of luck! And I DO mean that.
As said, it's not a bad game and I will continue to play it. But little things here and there irk me enough to make me not recommend it to people. I also really wish the PvP battles really were PvP and not against the AI. I think this would have made a fun and unique element to throw in.
voteText: 15 of 24 people (63%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Been playing this game for a while now, and I have concluded that it's not really worth mentioning.
I will now explain why:

* The luck factor is a bit ridiculous. You can be CLEARLY winning a match, just to have one move by the CPU wipe out your entire side, all due to luck. This could be viewed as a fun gameplay mechanic, but it just comes across as overwhelmingly frustrating. It takes away from the fun of the game, and should be changed.

* It's good this game is free-to-play, because spending money on it would be horribly stupid. Nothing that can be bought with real money is worth it, and the whole game can be experienced without paying. Again, don't waste any of your money on this game.

* Here it is 25Jan2015, and the game still has it's Xmas theme. Music, loading screens, etc. It's no longer Xmas guys, wake up. How much longer are we going to have to listen to Xmas carols this year?

All in all, if you're looking for a simple puzzle game to kill 10-15 mins, this will kinda work. If you're looking for anything deeper than that, don't waste the space on your HDD with this throughly below average game.

reviewText:
If Magic the Gathering and Bejeweled would have a baby it probably would off been this game.

This Game is a nice Match 3 Puzzle Game with flashy colours and RPG Elemtens. Unlike other Match 3 Games this requires alot of thinking and is more Strategy orientated like Magic the Gathering. Similiar to Magic the Gathering you can also unlock in this game cards that give you new Creatures" aka Troops.

As this is a Free to play Game you of course have the option to pay Real Money to open Treasure Chest but you do not have to. It seems like you only can get surtian Armors if you pay Real Money. But anything else seems to be also earnable by just playing the game.

I personally haven't tried the PVP as there is no Valve Anti-Cheat in the game so I can't say anything about it just yet. Although I do recommend this game to any RPG
date: Strategy and Bejeweled Fan.\n\nIn my opinion this is one of the better Free to Play Games on Steam."

reviewText: I understand why a game should provide challenges.  Victory is meaningless without them. Outmaneuvering a game like this can be immensely satisfying and well worth your efforts.  On the other end of the spectrum,  constantly losing a game - any game - that overwhelms you with unecessarily difficult or next-to-impossible challenges quickly becomes frustrating, if not infuriating, and that's what's going on in Gems of War. ft doesn't take long for you to realize that the developers are in total control of every outcome of every match you play here, that random number generators, luck and skill have nothing whatsoever to do with the experience.  No matter what you do, how many guilds you join, how often you allow them to post to your Facebook page, or how many dollars you throw at this game to embellish your troops or your main character, once you reach the advanced level of the game, you will not win.  Gems of War doesn't want to challenge you.  It wants to make you angry, and at that it truly succeeds.\n\nPlay this game long enough and you'll see for yourself:  at a certain point, the AI literally takes control of the match and gives itself 6 turns in a row to your every 1.  Super powered monsters come out of their respective lairs and blow your characters to smithereens leaving you sitting there slack jawed and stunned, with nothing to show for your efforts.  Blatantly rigging a game in this manner is audacious and mean spirited, not to mention just plain stupid.  There's not even any attempt to make it appear as though you lost the match fair and square.  The end result: every reason you may have ever had for playing Gems of War is obliterated.  No wonder it's free.  Delete it off your hard drive and never look back.

reviewText:
Do you like matching 3 things in a line?  What am I asking? Who doesn't like matching 3 things in a line!

Gems of War mixes the ultimate game mechanic (match-3) with some more pretty popular game mechanics (RPG levelling, card collecting and turn-based combat) in a free-to-play package that's hard to beat from the makers of Puzzle Quest.

Your progress carries across between Steam and iOS/Android so you can get your RPG match-3 fix anywhere (anywhere you've got internet that is).

The price to get three-matching is a low, low zero dollars - what are you waiting for?

reviewText:
There is a lot to love and a lot to hate in Gems of War, but at its core, it is an enjoyable game to play. There is something elegent about mashing together a match 3 and deck building game. Being a match 3, there is always an element of luck to winning. There is also a lot of skill that goes into building a good deck. The two are as balanced as it gets.

Despite being an always online game with guild and chat features, it is a single player game. Even the PVP feature puts you against a player created team controlled by AI. This is the biggest thing I can fault the game for. I would love if the game were to have true PVP, or at least an offline mode.

Being a F2P game, I must also mention the payment model. The game currently follows a pay to grind less model. While everything except the newest piece of armor is obtainable for free, it will take a long time to get normally in game. Currently, the amount of available troops is expanding faster than I can generate resources to upgrade them. If you are a completionist who likes variety, this may become an expensive and time consuming game for you. However, if you can pick out your favorites and stick to them, you will never need to spend a dime to enjoy the game.

reviewText:
When I first started playing it was fun and interesting...Latest upgrades to game has morphed it into  a game that is less fun.

It was a nice casual game without too much stress/complexity.  I thought it was great when they would bring out new cards and new kingdoms to fight in - kept it interesting and fresh.

Alhogh a free game, I would have bought the game in original format but now not willing to.

I find myself playing this less now with all the changes -harder to find things and really seems intended for playing on phones -not laptops or desktops.

Developers should have just issued a Gem of War 2" and left the orignial alone when they started monkeying with the game play/interface/leveling etc.

With the new leveling is too complicated - I play many of other RPG games that I like the complex systems but this was just a casual game.  I want to play a casual game  when I do not have the time or the focus to get that deep into the gameplay.

Mr. Developer...decide what you want the game to be.  Do not change so drastically if it is working - you may lose more players than you gain."

reviewText:
This is a game where they simply got the underyling difficulty wrong before we even get into any of the other issues.  This game is predicated on two extremely broken concepts:

1.  The person who moves first in this game (which is you) has an overwhelming advantage in a short game.
2.  The AI is overwhelmingly stronger than most players in a long game.

So you start your game and you're easily able to leverage your first move advantage and beating the AI down easily, and you think this is a fair game for a F2P or that you're just so awesome at this game.  Then, eventually the game gets longer as AI comes with more complete teams + higher level teams with HP values your team can't touch.  Since the AI pretty much never evaluates a match 4/5 or a skull situation wrong, eventually you're going to make a bad move and watch the AI merciless pound your guys to oblivion.  Now this is where most reviews will claim the game is P2W or the AI is cheating.  But it's not that.  Even if you spent hundreds of dollars on the game your slightly stronger team will still get pounded horribly whenever you make a mistake, but if you got enough money on your guys you might be able to withstand the barrage.  Of course, for those who aren't big spenders you'll simply lose and run out of your gold.  You can try again or grind some more but overall it doesn't change the fact that as games drag on, you'll simply be beaten by AI's flawless evaluation of the key scenarios, and evaluating those scenarios correctly determines the winner about 90% of the time.

Of course, the lack of information on your cards from an in game source makes any attempt to put together a team a wild guess at best.  There are skills that reads like does 2 + damage based on number of reds".  How much damage?  You don't know unless you check a forum for a guy who has worked out the math.  So you face a significant deficit and you don't even necessarily know how your skills will work.  Can you expect this guy to be able to tank or that guy to be able to do damage at level 10?  Better check a guide elsewhere
date: because this information isn't available in the game short of leveling the character up yourself
recommended: and there's no way you can afford to do that just as an experiment.\n\nI suspect if you spent enough time/money on the game you'll eventually reach some kind of equilibrium where you have enough high level characters with enough cheap skills to reduce the average game to a length short enough to be even
hoursPlayed: but I don't know why anyone should be expected to put up with the abuse on the way getting there.  The game by design is meant to hurt and I guess you win when you can overcome the beating.  Or you can just not play the game."

reviewText:
TLDR F2P? P2W? Nah, just L2P!

Long version:
Is this Free to Play or Pay to Win? No, it's just Learn to Play! If you do, you will not need to pay anything in the store. Of course you could buy something to support the devs. I suggest a good armour that increases your winnings of gold and souls.

So Learn to Play!

Here are a few tips. This is not really a match-3, it is a match-4! A match-4 gives an extra turn. The AI is not cheating as so many lazy guys have been complaining about, it follows certain rules of its own, always! So find them out and use it against it. It always does match-4 first even if there are spells or skull moves that could make it win the game, then it does skulls, them spells. It almost never does anything clever, like a move that will create a cascade of matches. This gives you the chance to outwit it. I regularly can win an opponent 3 times stronger than me. At level 200 I could beat the level 1000 opponents. But if I am not careful or if I play a new combination of troops I may easily lose by an opponent half my level. Use the quests and the challenges to learn the best conbinations for you. Study the opponent to find which troops are the really dangerous ones. In other words Learn to Play! Then join a guild and play PvP. It no longer costs gold to play so you can play as much as you like, and you get traitstones, gold and souls to help you upgrade.

The original Puzzle Quest was one of my best games. This one is even better. Thoroughly recommended!

reviewText:
I've been a big Bejewelled! fan when that game had been released. I've  played puzzle quest for months and enjoyed it.
So I've expected this game will give me similar joyful hours. BUT NO.

This game is an obvious example when the developers are clearly lack of programming skills. They were unable to create an AI that notices even the smallest combos on the board. The enemies are really stupid, It's so easy to trick the AI into disadvantageous situations. ... and there comes the most lame solution from developers. The AI cheats. So openly and hilariously. After playing like 200+ matches I've seen many situations when practically impossible gem layouts formed for the AI by the replacement gems falling in from the top. Like 7-8 skulls in a row, continuous combos for 7-10 steps, exactly the missing color to complete a 4 or a 5 that makes the AI win in desperate situations. etc. If the same would happen to me sometimes I'd say ok. It's some kind of a random. But no. Only for the AI and only when I'm ranking up too fast".

Summary: Good concept
recommended: but the worst incompetent programming in the genre I've ever seen."

reviewText: This was fairly fun for about a day or two. After reaching level 15 the game increases in difficulty really fast and there seems to be no way to grind. The only way to level troops is through collecting (or buying) souls. Souls are obtained through challenges but again that difficulty spikes quickly as well. Fixing the mechanics to at least allow for some grinding through replaying levels would make this a great game. As it currently stands though, it is very much a pay to win (or at the very least pay to not tear your hair out). Making better use of gold as a resource vs an energy source would make this a much better gaming experience. It is playable and even fun here and there, but I wouldn't put too much time into it.\n\nLooked into PvP to make some gold as suggested by another poster. I was put up against higher levels EVERY time and usually they were 15-20 levels higher. There are zero checks and balances that would make this a fun game for the casual gamer.

Now two of those require you have enough gold to play a game to gain the gold to play another game. Not useful when you haven't got enough to play a game. The other option means waiting, so I now can not play this game until some 24 hours after this post.

So in short, if you fancy something you can do stuff on every now and then, the I recommend this game to you. If you're looking for something to last a bit longer, then I suggest you look for something else, which is what I'm now doing.

I think I'll come back to this tomorrow, but I don't know how many tomorrows I'll be willing to put up with before I just play something else instead.

reviewText:
they removed needing gold to do fights on here pve or pvp woot

anyways so i have not played that long of this due to that technincally being only able to do so much per day

so this game as most can probably guess is like puzzle quest and that is accurate

like in any game you don't start off very strong but you can get stronger by lvling up your hero and increasing the lvls of your units

you can get more units by consuming keys which you can earn by doing battles or spend some gold to get more units to

now why would you want more then 1 of the same unit well if you want to have more then 1 of the same unit in your team of up to 4 that includes your hero

but also because you can ascend that unit if you have enough copys of them which makes them stronger and raises their max lvl

it looks like you can ascend them up to mythic by looking at info that idk if it's still up to date though or not exactly

like if a unit starts at common but you ascend it once then your going to need other copys ascended once as well in oreder to ascend the first unit again

you can lvl up your units by spending souls on them which you also get from battles

all the currencys are well gold of course and then there is glory which is gaind by doing pvp battles and lastly gems the cash shop currency

there is also guilds which can provide perks from being in them as well as overs tasks to be done which you complete by seting gold to them as a guild so anyone can put gold to it

you can gain various things from the guild tasks like this currancy used for by the top ranking ppl in the guild to add bonuses to everyone as well as one can gain gems from the guild task that's right one can earn gems

so if your dedicated enough you can own everything in this game just like most free 2 play games though they would like you to buy from the cash shop but it is doable without spending anything again it's how dedicated are you

and lastly this is a free 2 play game what do you have to lose by trying it out right

i forgot to mention about there is certain other things you can unlock after doing enough quests like the arena and picking a class and other hero related cards well powers

i knew there would be a wall so to speak but man you hit it hard early on idk what i am supossed to be trying to farm at a lower lvl i'm starting to get discouraged here

so why have i changed it to down? well it's because of how much stuff was broken by the 2.0 patch including pvp which is where you would go to in order to start earning more gold per battle from quests and challanges

but pvp is broken so as a newer player your stuck with quests that only get harder each time and challanges it's just to much time needs to be put in for to little out of it

once they fix stuff up more i will change this to an up arrow again and if your a new player hold off on this game till they fix things will save your self some fustration

edit 4
looks like i can do pvp matches again why such a fuss over if i can do pvp or not well
do you want to do 1 battle that could earn you 150+ gold if you win or would you rather do many quest/challange battles to earn as much from 1 pvp battle and the fact that you gain glory to from pvp

now they might not have everything quite fixed up yet but i think they have most important things working

Listen, first off, do NOT listen to ANY other reveiw than this one. All of the others are out of date, or they havent spent enough time with the game to appreciate it.

What you should note: This game has an incredibly steep learning curve, you will have to play for awhile to get the hang of it, and IT DOES NOT REQUIRE ANY- AND I MEAN ANNNYYYY Money to get into, and its fun to play when you dont have a lot to do, you CANNOT play online with another player- you ALWAYS have to fight CPU.

The story to this game sucks. I'm going to be frank, its terrible. But thats not why you should play it. This game is about the stratigy and a bit of luck is involved. If you arent into these puzzle-type games, this will be one that may change your mind, like it did mine.

The main goal of the game is to proceed through the kingdoms and beat all of the, i guess, campeigns. Even after you do this, you still have MANY hours of play with PVP and Challenges. (Once again, PVP is you vs a CPU with another players team)

reviewText:
Past experiences should have taught me to steer clear of this cancer of the gaming world that goes by the label of 'Free to Play' games. Sadly, I find myself unable to resist them way too often. Thus I tried Gems of War. The wisest course of action would be to abandon this abomination and prevent further headaches. But then my Steam account would forever be besmirched by my horrible achievement completion rate in this game (30% at the moment).

I fear my pride won't let me take the easy way out.

This game has many of the usual annoying Free to Play aspects we all love. The daily login bonus, popups to inform you about the newest ways to spend your money and sure enough not only the shop button but another button which leads to the aforementioned deals. Because the popup isn't sufficient.
There are worse offenders out there. I know that because I played some of them. That doesn't absolve the developers of Gems of War. They knew what they created when they did it. So shame on them!

As for the game itself, it is a long tedious grind. Basically you assemble your army by collecting cards which represent the individual troops. Each one has different abilities, some of which are actually interesting and allow fun combinations and synergies.
But then you have to level these cards up. And that takes effort. The currency needed can be bought (of course, lol) or acquired in the match-3 gamemode this all is about. The latter method takes a lot of effort. Especially if you want to swap out your cards from time to time, to experiment or because you found a better combination of troops you want to use.

The artwork is mediocre and the dialogue is downright horrible. The protagonist mostly speaks in one-word-sentences. Why?"
date:
"Okay." and "Hmm..." make up a big portion of his contributions. Great! I always wanted to play a halfwit who is barely able to talk.

The way you get screwed over constantly by the cheating AI is another bottomless source of joy.


Update: After playing this for quite some time now
recommended: my opinion has changed slightly to the better. Once I had a decent pool of troops and the souls to level them up to a usable level the gameplay became significantly less frustrating. But therein lies a huge designflaw. If you have to grind a game for 20+ hours before it gets fun I can't recommend it."

reviewText:
I love Puzzle Quest.
I don't really like Free-to-play games.

I can't really see that I will need to pay any money. (Though I might one day to support the devs)
Getting plenty of in game currency to level up and unlock more troops.
Already have about 4 rare troops after about 7 hours play.
Give it a go. It's a small download.
Looks and plays awesome.
Better than Marvel Puzzle Quest in my opinion.

reviewText:
Good
- Tutorial that is not intrusive to get you into the game
- Easy to learn and play
- Quest system
- New unit cards can be unlocked you can choose from
- New weapons can be collected and equipped as quest loot


Bad
- Always online
- Paywall as progression killer - it's based on time and ingame currency, like most other waiting simulators out there that give you the choice to either wait to replenish or you have to pay

When i was in the best mood after completing the unintrusive tutorial and wanted to actually start playing the game, i ran out of Gold needed to play any further, if you don't want to pay moneyZZZ at that point, you get a boring waiting-game. It's as bad as any other browsergame that makes you wait for stuff happen or pay to continue"

If you don't care about the paywall or the fact that you run out of ingame currency and have to wait for some time to replenish it
recommended: give it a go but for me it killed the mood

reviewText:
Product received for free

Great game, I love the cynical humor of the characters (don't skip the chat!) and the way you don't always know if you are helping the good guy or the bad guy until the story plays out.  It is hard to work a decent story into a match-3 game, but they managed it pretty well.
There is PvP in the game, but at this point, it is totally optional.  You can and will get attacked by other players, but they are limited to taking a certain percentage of the gold you accrued while offline, not emptying your bank account.
The PvP ranking system is a little sketchy, but can work in your favor as often as against it.  You can be level 100 and get ranked against a level 295 but then 'try another match' and get a level 45.  I have no idea what stat it matches you up by, but be patient and you can do well.
There are guilds in the game.  There is no guild chat as you may know it in other games, but instead there is a message board.  The advantage to that is the messages STAY, so you can talk or give messages to players who aren't on at the same time you are.
Guild quests are simple.  Give a little extra gold when you can.  You pay to fill the quest bar.  You don't need to be uber skilled to help your guild.
The skills and abilities of your troops was greatly expanded about the time I quit playing, so I can not add a lot to that, but it creates a lot of depth and customization for fighting style and powers, that you really would not expect in a game that seems so simple on the surface.
Pay to Win.  Nope.  Simple as that.  Pay to speed things up?  Yeah, of course.  Dev's don't live and work for free.  But there is no gameplay advantages to buying other than to get stuff done faster.  You can patiently grind away to get those runestones and still get those talents on your troops you want without paying.  It will just take a bit longer.  I really like that.  It kept the game from feeling like it was descending into a stale cash grab.
The game is still vibrant and alive with active devs and a lot of players.  I hope it continues to thrive.

reviewText:
Product received for free

I downloaded this game off a whim, expecting it to be a fairly generic match-3 game, that would probably devolve into pay-to-win rather quickly. I was pleasantly surprised to find it otherwise. The RPG elements actually intergrate surprisingly well with the puzzle match-3 elements. Now, there are rather a lot of options for microtransactions, and, when I first started playing, it seemed like levelling troops would be extremely painful. However, this was before I discovered the minigames.  Both the arena and the Zhul'Kari Treasure hunt give potentially high yields of gold and souls, with the Zhul'Kari treasure hunt providing free to play players a means of slowly acquiring gems, and thus high rarity units. Once you start playing those two minigames, the power progression proceeds at a quite reasonable rate.

The most obvious complaint I have about the game is that the quests are written, well, kinda terribly. The characters you quest with are rather centred around a very basic archetype with no development beyond that, and the player character has no personality whatsoever. While I haven't seen anywhere near all the quests, the four I've started on (three of which I've completed) have all been a fairly formulaic near-solitary lawful good hero campaigning against large chaotic evil force. Maybe I'm just refusing to see some elements somehow, but it's almost impossible to get invested in the stories. I do understand the plot isn't the point, and the brief dialogs are not really enough to convey any depth, and the attempt at plot is appreciated. Nonetheless, how flat this falls is my one true complaint about the game.

tl;dr Gameplay's great; story, though the attempt is appreciated, kinda sucks.

reviewText:
This game is complete and utter crap. Gameplay wise, its fine. There is nothing really overly that you have to do in terms of thinking. Its straight forward. Monster abilities are weak, or a joke. The AI of the game that picks the gems for you, is heavily geared towards your opponent. Sure you match 3, then they match one and get 4 turns, skulls to decimate your troops. And u watch it all happen while shaking your head.

Gold is a bit absurd, two days without playing to get enough to get another kingdom open to do some quests. And THEN it costs gold to battle the quests? Lots of things need fixed. A patch over for balance might be useful, actually it is really needed. I beleive other users have said it as well.

This game is fun, when for lack of a better term its not cheating. Getting troops to a manageable level is funny to say the least. You dont really get enough souls to upgrade with, your frustrated to the point of just closing the game down. And so matches you play against, you are just getting destroyed.

So, i think a good balance patch is in order, look at the gold spending for quests (i mean seriously?) Buying a kingdom seems to scale with your level. Which is stupid. Make the kingdoms a set amount of gold and be done with it. if it happens and they fix alot of issues i might change the review to reccommend.

reviewText:
Gems of War is free to play and many of the cards obtainable only from ingame earned currency so you need to play and can not buy with money. The developers have made the game so you can buy with crystals if you are patient everything. Also I have obtained 2 legendaries from silver keys and a joining a guild after level 25 is worth your time as the people donate more gold and you usually get at least 18 silver keys and 30 crystals each week.
The game is progression based and you can earn higher level cards by farming souls such as using the valkyre and brian the lucky cards together (60 souls cap per battle).
I do prefer this free to play style game where waiting will get you everything slowly vs other companies using a clear abuse of paying to win tactic you can never obtain paid content/rewards - these games I refuse to play. I will always donate some money for the developers as they are fairer than other companies.
I play divination fields challenge 1 over and over to progress now i have finished all the stories. This game can be linked to your phone so you can play in your lunch break or even walking or to relax. I have never run out of gold and PVP rank does not drop if you lose matches so you do not go backwards.
Thumbs up from me for a fun Gem match RPG game and other puzzle quest games.

reviewText:
This is a fun crossover for people who like match-3 games and deck-building elements.

It's free-to-play that you really CAN enjoy without paying for any of the extras. (Although many people do choose to get the extras, which help pay for the servers and ongoing development.) The development team is responsive to bug reports and is continually adding and improving features. The game was fun a year ago, and it's only continued to improve from there.

You play match-3 vs an AI-operated enemy. Great if you get frustrated by slow players or people who rage-quit mid-game in PVP. Unsatisfying if you really crave the challenge of matching wits against another human. (I love it!)

You operate a character that gains experience with each game, and gains access to new special abilities as you raise gem mastery levels. You can collect allies with various stats and abilities. Special abilities are fuelled by different-coloured gems. As your collection of allies grows, you can mix and match them into teams (the deck-building element), and you can even replace your main character while continuing to earn experience. You can use resources to level up allies and give them additional special abilities.

There are guilds available, which allows you to gain resources more quickly (just for logging in!), chat (or not), and contribute toward group rewards. Winning PVP matches while you're in a guild will raise that guild's level and improve the rewards available.

There are a range of different ways to play:
----------------------------------------------------------------
* Storyline quests where you play versus pre-designed teams" of enemies. Completing storylines can increase resources available.

* Challenge matches where you battle key questline teams at higher and higher difficulty (a real challenge early in the game
date:
often not any more difficult than the main quest once you get to higher levels). Completing matches gives you additional resources for levelling-up allies.

* PVP matches where you fight against teams designed by other players. (Opposing teams are still played by AI.) This can be a good way to earn in-game resources more quickly.

* Arena matches where you you create a team on-the-fly from limited options presented
recommended: including allies you may not have available in your current troop listing
hoursPlayed: to play against other teams generated by players in the arena. (This is especially fun if you get frustrated facing over-optimized teams
voteText: because the randomization and limited scope evens the field for deck-building strategy.) It costs in-game gold to play
helpfulPercent: so it might be harder to access for new players
votesHelpful: but this is a resource that continually regenerates and the cost for arena matches quickly becomes negligible.\n\n* Treasure hunts which are a different style of match-3 game. It is single player (so there is no opposing team that manipulates the board) and matched gems join to one upgraded gem
votesTotal: so the strategy can be quite different. This costs maps to play
votesFunny: which can be obtained with long combos in the other games or purchased with in-game glory. As with arenas
commentsCount:
these resources quickly become easy to access.
----------------------------------------------------------------

Basically
column16: if you like match-3 games with a little extra
column17: there's probably something here for you! Games are quick
column18: so you can just pop in and back out without losing a large portion of your day."

reviewText:
Gems of War is a strategy based game, with plenty to do.

The main objective of the game is to match gems to attack oponents (CG or PVP) however there is more to do than this, which is what I find sets it apart from almost all other similar style games.

There are specialities, which focus on which gems give extra mana (which allows you to use special moves quicker)
You can also gain souls, which are used to level up your characters. With hundreds, if not thousands of different characters with different abilities and majoring in different gem colours, there are so many combinations to create to make your team all-powerful.

Guilds are also an increasing important role (ahem, mines is WARMACHIN3"). Guild participation allows for additional keys for treasure chests (these give characters
date: as well as other cool stuff)
recommended: gold (this helps progress to other areas)

reviewText:
Solid game. Surpisingly deep RPG/CCG systems layered on top of a matching game. I'm not a big puzzle gamer but I find the RPG stuff makes it pretty fun. reviewText:
A match 3 game with a nice little twist.  You collect troop cards to build on and level up throughout the game, and it's the strength of your team that helps you win each match.  You can join a guild and earn numerous rewards.  There's a LOT of hours of game play in this game!

You have to earn gold to take part in things throughout the game, and I see numerous negative reviews complaining about how they have no gold to do things throughout the game.  I don't understand...even as a casual player, I've earned more than enough gold to do just about anything that I want in the kingdom, and still have a cushion.

The game can be highly addictive, if you like match 3 games.  It's not just a mindless match 3 game, either.  You have to plan out your moves, otherwise you could end up in some serious trouble.

Of course, you have the option to purchase diamonds to buy special chests and other things in-game, but you can also purchase chests with gold and glory that you earn; although they're not as high class" as the diamond chests
date: they're pretty good nonetheless.  Anything you need...except for the diamonds
recommended: of course...can be earned in numerous different ways throughout the course of the game.\n\nThe game play itself is a lot of fun. Depending on what sort of troop you're playing against
voteText: or it can be an intensive grind match that lasts and lasts.  It's the grind matches that give you a serious sense of accomplishment in the game when you win one
helpfulPercent: which is something that you really don't find in other match 3 games.\n\nOverall
votesHelpful: I think this is an excellent game
votesTotal: and well worth a try for even the most serious match 3 game player!"

reviewText:
I love Gems of War!

I have played this through on the PS4 and am happily playing through again on the PC.

The game itself is of the match 3 or more gems genre such as Puzzle Quest and a more advanced version of Bejewled Blitz.
Create teams, fight battles and use the troops you gather to win through the challenges and Invasions. There are numerous 'lands' to unlock, each with it's own campaign, set of challenges which are unlocked as the campaign progresses, plus extra acheivments levels specific to the land (arena, treasure maps). The campaigns are not overly long, but fun none the less and when there are 8 or more lands to complete, the game becomes a great past time. Believe me, time disappears playing from battle, to challenge, to invasion, to a defence- I played this until 5am having started to play at 23.00 - I could have sworn I was only playing for 20 minutes instead of the 6 hours I enjoyed.

Level up yourself and troops by earning souls, gems, cash and glory. Use a combination of troops, and move their order in the team to find the perfect combo; some troops are useful to use with others and some troops are specifically complimentory to one another. It's trial and error but good heavens it is fun finding out what works and what doesn't.

The PC version differs from the PS4 version I play in that one is British and the other American- the troops can differ between the two and the layout is slightly different- plus one take £ the other $ for extra items like gems to spend in game on souls $ gold in order to open chests gain troops and be the best- but who cares what denomination is required!!!!!!!!

Gems of War is by far and away the best game in the match 3 or more genre I have played- and I have played these games to death. Pay no mind to my steam game time- I am level 71 going on 72 on the PS4 with over 40 hours game time- I really love this game!

So bust them gems and bring the enemy down. Oh and HAVE FUN!

AngelDelight81 x

reviewText:
I love Gems of War, which is no surprise since I played Puzzle Quest 1 & 2 until my daughter was old enough to snag them from me.

I started playing this game on mobile actually and unless you don't tab out (since it caused the game to restart when you come back in) or need the computer screen to see better (I had no idea how much I was squinting while playing mobile though I do need glasses), I’d suggest going with mobile. But that’s personal preference biased since that’s how I started and touch screen feels better, and I’m usually multitasking all the time so the tabbing out problem bothers me.

I don't think it's pay to win or that the AI cheats. I've gone pretty far while being a completely free player: lvl 85 with 50 troops, all kingdoms unlocked, rank 1 pvp and 41 free gems (40 from guild, one from cascade of 7 matches). You just have to pay attention to the board and sometimes switch troops around. There is more strategy than just troops (though that’s a big part of it), like denying the enemy mana, which enemies to prioritize, and forcing the enemy into giving you better matches.

Luck, of course, plays a role but I’ve only had to re-do a handful of quest battles that swung against me to beat it with the same team right afterwards. Most of the time when the AI gets huge cascades I’m kicking myself because I missed something or gave them the matches.

There was a bit of frustration in the beginning but branching out to other kingdoms to lvl and get purple troops helped solve a lot of that and really upped my PVP game. I’d also suggest joining a guild asap as the bonus help as does the task rewards. My main team also utilized every color instead of doubling up but I’ve seen some killer teams that do it differently.

As far as PVP is concerned, it’s when I have to defend against extreme higher lvls that I get decimated but that’s not a pay2win problem. I have beaten legendary teams and gotten legendary troops from iron keys.

I’ve been searching for a game like this since Puzzle Quest and have finally found it. :)

reviewText:
There is NOTHING to recommend here. Move along. Gems have been sold away for P2W game.

The Gameplay, visuals and pretty much anything that COULD'VE been entertaining is DOA.
You have to pay STUPIDLY large sums of Gold to PvP battle people. Both players pay gold and one wins it all. Sounds interesting yeah? WRONG! Match making is broken and will que you up against Level 40's and 50's while you're level 8.
In order to get someone else, more your freakin' level you have to PAY to find another person. WTF. Why do I have to pay just to actually have fair matchmaking? Heck, even when I DO PAY, I can still get a person of an even HIGHER level.

Then on TOP of all of that, for EVERY. SINGLE. CAMPAIGN MISSION YOU MUST PAY IN GOLD! You Pay to unlock areas. You pay to play missions. You pay to PvP. Pay, pay, pay. Seriously, there is more Paying in this game than in Dungeon Keeper Mobile by EA.

And it doesn't even count the P2W model of gameplay where you can not only pay for awesome cards but you can pay for awesome HERO weapons as well.

TL;DR, Stick with the better Puzzle Quest games and stay away from this utter Abomination of a game.

0/10 Needs more Pay to Win -IGN

reviewText: The shine has gone off it. While I commend the team for bringing out major updates to often, the host of additions they have added to the game have made it almost impossible for a casual player (i.e. ones not willing to spend hundreds of dollars in real-world money) to have a fair chance to win. I have been playing for over a year, and enjoying it for the most part, and up until a month ago I would have given it a thumbs up without hesitation. However, recent changes to the game have completely destroyed any semblance of balance. It is now pay-to-win, and I'm just not interested in that. I haven't given up on it entirely, but I doubt I'll be a daily player any more.

reviewText:
Neat game, but like others have said the AI get exceptionally and coincidentally lucky a good portion of the time. It doesn't matter how strategic you are, the AI gets lucky drops way too often. Of course, if you like a challenge, this can be fun. Another thing, you're unlikely to earn back the gold you spend for each game.

This is starting to look like a pay to win game, or at the very least pay to play. For every kingdom you purchase the price goes up for the next kingdom. They do run weekly events where you earn extra gold and glory, but it really does start to drag on soon as the price for a new kingdom is in the 1-2+k range.

You can earn keys by random drops to unlock new cards or purchase keys with gold, but a lot of the cards are duplicates.

This game is addictive and will keep you occupied until you run out of gold.

It is an aesthetically pleasing game, but unless you feel like spending money or have the patience of a saint, it's probably not going to be a very enjoyable experience. It certainly isn't for everyone.

reviewText:
Only writing this because the negative reviews of this game amaze me.  The two main complaints I see are:

1)The AI cheats.
2) It's a pay to win game.

First, the AI doesn't cheat.  There is an element of luck involved in what new gems drop into the board, but it's absolutely fair.  Making smart plays will almost always mitigate the effect of luck on a game as well.  If you're counting on a lucky gem or skull to fall in place for you, then you're the one who's put you in the bad spot of relying on luck, and there is/was likely a better play available.  When I lose, it is almost always due to poor decisions, not poor luck.

Second, I've logged over 300 hours, eclipsed level 100, gotten the second most expensive armor set in the game, and done all of it without spending one cent of real world money.  I have never encountered any situation in the game that made me feel like I hit a paywall.  I've earned over 500 gems (the real world currency) just through guild rewards.  Earning gold becomes rediculously easy after the first few hours of gameplay.  It really is free to play and free to win, I promise.

I'm not saying this game is the best thing ever, and certainly it won't be everyone's cup of tea, but as FTP games go, it is absoutely worth trying out.
