reviewText: MY VERDICT WILL BE AT THE END OF MY REVIEW:  I have been playing this game for my first day. So far, it is a good game, mainly based on the fact that IT IS FREE! Now, that being said, there are some good things and some maybe not so good things about this game. Of course, I haven't been able to get into all parts of the game, me being so new to it. But, for the parts that I can and have been able to: I have heard many negative reviews on the fact that AI gets way to many chances and/or attacks because the computer gets all the better combinations. Now, I haven't seen that as much as others...possibly because I haven't played as much as others. But, again, it is free people...what do you expect from a free game?  lol   Ok, I like the match-genre games, and this one is better than most I have played. Also, the fact that the matchings go directly to the gameplay makes this game awesome, as you really need to strategize your moves to win. Yes, there will be some luck and unknowing combinations that will arise(from the top of the gameboard when you make combinations as they fall down into the play area). I love the fact that it is a great storyline, and there are other mini-games involved. BUT, I do now see why most of the reviewers complain about the lack of game money here. Each battle costs roughly 50g in game money. But, IF you win, the game only gives you UP TO 23g game money per battle(in my case of where i am at in my game). So, I do agree after playing the game an hour or so, you will most likely need to stop just on the basis that you run out of money...that sucks. I will never ever pay my own money for a free game, I do like the quality and graphics. I would like to see some patches or changes in the money side of the game. Oh, also, one last irk I have is when you level up, you don't have the option to relegate where your points go. The computer adds them at random(which I don't care for). I enjoy games where I can personally deal with points I get from leveling.\n\nOk, so now for my verdict: Yes, I would recommend this game to others.  Thank you for viewing my review, and happy game-playing Gems of War!!!!!!

reviewText:
Okay, personally I absolutely LOVE this little game.  The gem matching is fun and intuitive, if not especially innovative -- but where this game really shines is the way that many other elements are incorporated into a brilliant game that's bigger than the sum of its parts.

I find the RPG / Strategy elements to be well-done and think they add a lot to the game, in particular.  You have constant control over what you choose to do -- quests, raids, challenges, which troops to level up, which masteries to pursue, which weapon to use, and how to build your banners -- and it's absolutely great in that you can play it for 5-10 minutes on a break... or for hours at a time.

Yes, like many free games there are micro-transactions.  But you quite literally needn't EVER do a single one to fully enjoy this game.  I think kids these days" are impatient and can't -- or don't want to -- deal with a typical RPG "grind"
date: and if you want you can basically buy your way through that.  And
hoursPlayed: the sky is the limit on the amount of money you COULD spend on this game potentially.  Aside from that basic impatience
voteText: I am aware some people probably compulsively buy crap in micro-transactions... so if you're like that it may be best to stay away.\n\nPersonally
helpfulPercent: after playing this for quite a while now (getting a great deal of enjoyment from it clearly) I have just today spent the first actual cash on this game -- $4.99.  But you can play through the story of this game for HOURS without spending a penny.  THAT is what a good free-to-play should be; other developers ought to take note."

reviewText:
Gems of War is an interesting and rather fun twist on the Bejeweled-clone formula that so, SO many puzzle games (Candy Crush Saga, anyone?) copy. Like all Bejeweled clones, Gems of War is a match-three-gems game at its core, with a bonus if you match four or five. But the goal of the game is the kicker- the shell around the match-three-gems field isn't that of a puzzle game, but instead, that of a turn-based RPG with attacks and spells! It seems extremely polished gameplay wise, and is extremely engaging- and FUN.

And then you get into the rather confusing system- er, systems- of currency.

First, you have gold. You get gold pretty easily in game, even getting small amounts for small things like matching 4 or 5 gems- but it, as far as I have seen so far, goes absolutely nowhere, and has zero uses. This confused me to no end when I checked out the store to see if I could get a new costume.

Then you have the ACTUAL first in-game currency, souls, which are used for leveling up your allies- and that seems to be it.

Second, you have the real-money currency, gems. And it's used for buying EVERYTHING in the shop, except for itself- you, of course, need real money to buy gems. And the thing that irks me the most is that although you have no use for gold, you can buy it with gems- and although souls are pretty valuable as they're used to train allies, you can't buy them.

And fourth, there's Glory, the event-reward currency, used for buying extremely rare items.

Finally, as far as I could tell, there was no way to let my character try on a suit of armor before I could buy it. If a suit of armor is only for looks, let me see how it looks! (Even if I can't buy anything at all with gold.)

However, it IS a rather new game, so the stellar gameplay takes the cake here. Upvote with little hesitation.

reviewText:
I love it!
Yes, it is a free card/3-in-a-row game but you can actually play it without buying stuff from the in-game store, without any notable/important limits.

Use a deck of cards to assemble a team, each with unique powers. To charge the powers you need to get enough 3 in a row of gems in the same color as your power. There is a storyline to it as well, as you go and unlock new kingdoms with new type of monsters and powers.

Although, the AI may suggest you moves, but I learned to not trust it. If you follow its advice, you usually end up with giving away opportunities to the AI instead. Try to find your own solutions instead.

Overall, a fun casual game.

and

and
3. Probably my least amount of concern goes to the generic soundtrack. I suggest Spotify or Youtube whilst playing.

Overall

reviewText:
A bit about this game
Gems of War is a puzzle/strategy game where to win you destroy the opposing players army before yours gets destroyed.
Different characters have certain abilities that fill up when you match a gem of the element assigned to that character. Some of these are offensive and some are defensive. The other way to deal damage is by matching 3 skulls on the board. Each character has the following attributes: Attack, defence, Magic and Health. Attack is how much damage you deal, defence is how much armor you receive, magic is what level of effect your abilities do (higher level = more powerful ability) and health is health.
I love puzzle games and the strategy part of it is a nice twist, unlike any puzzle game I've played before.
9/10

reviewText: I do enjoy this game, but there is one thing that does annoy me about it. The in-game limitations. You know those techniques games use to artificially prolong their life? What I mean is paying to be able to play. Yes it isn't needed, but you need to pay in-game gold to play every time. And what can you do after that? Well you have two option, either wait for your town to generate enough gold so you can play more, or pay up. Especially annoying is when you want to defend youself, you still have to pay gold and there is no guarantee you will be able to do it succesfuly. More often then not you will fail, cause the matchmaking isn't the greatest and almost always you will be facing someone with better characters then you. When your opponent is better the only thing you can count on is the board and that luckily sometimes does help, by giving you useful combinations.\nIt's not a bad game, you don't have to" pay to play
date: but it is definitely one of those games where paying helps

reviewText:
As addicted to this game as I am, I must say this game leads to a lot of rage quits.  The game is set up to make you lose more then any other game I have ever played, I have played Dwarf Fortress.  The AI cheats and will ♥♥♥♥ you over 9/10 of the time.  The majority of the time when the AI suggests a play for you the play it creates for itself to play against you that is much better, if it is not an attack it will create an extra turn for itself.  I have actually been in battles where the AI plays for 30-90 seconds before I get to have another turn.  Finally, I have had battles that I have been winning, got the AI down to 1-2 players left while I still have all 4, just for the AI to get 5 consectutive attacks, 2 of which were critical hits, and completely destroy me.  I will admit this is a bit of a rage review.

I do recommend this game but I don't, Steam doesn't have a nuetral option on recommend, it is addicting but it is also frustrating.  If you rage quit games easily this game is not for you.  If you rage quit and come back in an hour after you cool off then you will enjoy this game.

In response to the Dev comment to my review, I do have a couple strong teams that can ussually win most of the time, Mauraders/goblins are a strong group to fall back on when I need to, but I get tired of playing the same team all the time and will often switch between teams for more of a challenge, which often can lead to a rage quit.  On that note it is also frustrating during PVP to run into so many goblin/maurader/Zaejin teams, I often find it a relief when I run into a team strategy that is strong and completely different then what I typically run into.

As my opinion,

It's yet no Wizard101 or Neverwinter, but it is definetly a great game.

A fast-paced, click&switch game, Lunaria&Solaria game, which is including great story, and both easy and hard adventure. You can have allies, different weapons, you also get to pick your class, name, and you even gain levels! So far, I've only reached level 5, but I can see this game is really fun. It only takes 333mb of space. What makes the game harder, is that you have to pay with in-game gold or coins to unlock battles, which can be get by daily rewards and by playing games. You can also buy the gold, but I'd reccomend to keep it the hardcore way, so it doesn't make you quite as addicted to game. The story seems great. reviewText:
(+) Good puzzle/RPG fun, not P2W, very pretty hand-drawn graphics and music. And, you know, FREE.

(-) some of the voice-overs are annoying ('Mana Serge!' Is that some magical Sommelier?); Atlanta's cleavage is just improbable; also clearly racist against goblins (I kid, goblins rule!).

This is a real successor to the original puzzle quest games, with the same humour and over-the-top high fantasy sensibility. I was a fan of the Warlords games from the very start (I am that old) and I had kind of given up hope of ever seeing Etheria or the Warlords universe agin, but this will just about do. I kind of hope Steve Fawkner is involved in this behind the scenes, but if not - this is true to his previous work.

Edit: Looking at negative reviews, a lot of the criticisms are aimed at how to gain troops and the gold mechanic; with a bit of patience, neither is a problem. Some of the best troops are recruited by completing all the quests in a kingdom;  Quests = troops and XP (pro tip, get Divinion Fields and unlock Atlanta; forget what I said about cleavage). Completing quests opens challenges; Challenges = Souls to level up troops. Once you have some half-decent troops, invade your neighbours; losing still earns you enough to absorb the cost of attack, winning gains you around extra 100 gold each time. As I said, patience :)

reviewText:
I absolutely love this game. Easy to pick up and wonderfully addictive, with the added bonus of having lots of shiny armour, troop and weapon cards to collect. The best part about it is that, whether you're playing through the quests or pvp-ing, it's all about strategy and wits, not player level; the right combination of troop cards can be devastating to an opponent even if they're tens of levels higher than you.

I've seen lots of reviews here that claim the game is 'Pay2Win,' i.e. you have to buy things in-game with real-world cash in order to earn enough gold to even PLAY the game, never mind buy the shinies that give you an advantage. THIS IS NONSENSE. I'm now level 117 and play for an hour or so pretty much every evening, and I can honestly say, hand on heart, I have not spent a penny of real-world money to do that. All the shinies I've bought (like Epic troops and weapons, and armour that gives stat bonuses) I have bought purely with in-game currency which is EARNED BY PLAYING THE GAME. There is a very simple way to make enough gold to play as long as you want AND earn the shinies, and that's to join a guild (which is easy as pie) and help them earn trophies. Do that and the whole 'Pay2Win' thing isn't an issue.

PVP is well-handled, particularly if you're a bit timid about that aspect of the game. While the players you 'invade' or 'revenge' against ARE real players, you don't actually play them in real time; the game selects them randomly and then uses the troops they've selected in advance to play against you using the in-game AI. This removes the uncertainty of hanging around waiting for your opponent to make their move (the computer AI handles it instantly) and also stops you feeling guilty about taking a long time to make your own moves (since the computer AI doesn't care.) However, don't assume that this makes winning a pushover, just because you're 'only' playing a machine. As I previously mentioned, picking the right combination of troops can make or break a match, and with the gem-matching element being the main source of 'charging up' your troops the luck of how the gems fall plays a big part in determining both your and the computer's chances. PVP-ing is how you win trophies (and gold) for your guild, which brings its own bonuses that get better the more trophies your guild earns.

However, there's more to the game than just pvp. You can also play through the quests for each of the (currently) 18 kingdoms (you start with one and then 'unlock' the rest with the gold earned from playing.) Completing a quest either earns you more daily income from that kingdom or unlocks a Challenge, which you play through the five levels of to earn Souls (which you can use to level up your troops.) There's also an Arena option in the Broken Spire kingdom, where you're given the chance to pick three random cards to join your character and play against other players (handled the same way as for pvp, except the game AI has also chosen their random cards for them) in a series of up to 8 battles, to win trophies, gold, glory, souls and keys. And the Zul'Khari kingdom has a Treasure Hunt option, which you can use to earn more of the same providing you have a treasure map (which can be earned either through completing guild tasks, getting a super-cascade of seven gem-matches in a row or buying them with Glory points.)

In short, this game has the addictive thingy-matching of Candy Crush without the teeth-grindingly frustrating complicated extra bits (like bringing down the fruits and nuts, breaking the cages and exploding the bombs before the countdown runs out - admit it, you hate those things!) combined with the Top-Trumps-esque card battles with collectible troops and weapons. Fun on so many levels!

reviewText: My husband introduced me to this on XBox One. It's just as addictive as Bejeweled. In fact, it's like a cross between Bejeweled and Magic: The Gathering. All of the puzzles are in versus mode, so you have to be careful about setting up shots for your opponent. (I can be terrible about that.) You can level all of your cards/characters up as you see fit, though. There is a quest/storyline, but you get to choose which kingdoms to unlock. Completing all challenges and other requirements will level up a kingdom as well, though I haven't seen how that plays a part in things yet.\n\nFair warning, this game does have the option to buy things with real money. It's fairly minimal compared to most games, thankfully. While you can buy useful items and packages, it's not full of micro-transactions like Candy Crush or Frozen.

reviewText:
The game has been patched, let's rejoy and àplay it together again! ^_^

_____________________

Old review:

In this state, I just cannot in good conscience recommend this game. The concept is fun, they add a ton of new content regularly (new kingdoms / troops / weapons / game modes...). They also hold sales regularly to incite people to spend money, which is understandable.
BUT there is a major problem: they just don't fix bugs. Some have been going on since the Steam release and have NEVER been patched. Which makes the game infuriating, and sometimes downright unplayable (such as the AI getting free extra turns for no reason whatsoever, the worst offender bug of them all in my opinion, or having wins counted as losses, particularly damaging when playing the arena). Also, actual PvP is non-existent at the moment, which I believe is a shame.
So yeah, it's cool to add new content and ask people to give them money, but honestly, as long as they don't work on fixing what's broken before releasing new stuff, the game is just not worth it. Wait for them to fix the bugs before trying it out.

reviewText:
The layout and operation of this game is very unhelpful.

When you are fighting a single enemy, it wants you to select (click) the enemy you wish to use a targetted skill on, awful.

The biggest puzzle is what you are supposed to do to progress in the game. It gives you little or no information on what you will gain for completing a quest/challange/etc. Upgrading troops is likewise a big secret, until you spend the souls you have no idea what benefit it will give you. There is no preview for an upcoming battle, so you spend your gold only to find out you have no chance of winning.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
I love match 3 games and play them on just about every platform.

I like the concept of this game, but the technical execution is not good enough right now. From the general game interface and window management, to screen transitions between moves and levels. Feels very unpolished even though the artwork looks polished and the voiceover work is well done and on par with games of this nature. Sound effects are too heavy on the RPG-theme for such repetitivle gem clearing. And for me, the casual nature of a gem swapping game means that I will often jump back and worth with the game and other tasks on the computer. Blur the gameboard would be fine, but they switch to a completely different screen and the delay for transitions to keep playing, is too long.

Might be worth re-visiting in the future if they make some significant updates. For now, it was just too many annoying little issues to keep playing.

reviewText: As annoying as the free-to-play crap is, this game is the first match-3 battler I've played that really feels like a worthy successor to the original Puzzle Quest. At least it seems to have a way less awful buy-in scheme than Marvel: Puzzle Quest did --you can get a bunch of Legendary allies just from doing the story, and I've pulled some pretty a'ight ultra-rares from the free keys you occasionally get.\n\nGood times.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: I've been playing this game for quite some time. Took a break for almost a year and recently got back to it. There have been some good updates and improvements made in that time including more bonuses, more to spend gold on and more troops. One of the best improvements is adjustable difficulty. Base difficulty removes the cheating AI where they seem to magically have gems  they need drop down into crazy combos which is much needed to eliminate frustrations. Increasing it brings back that little bit of cheating and can increase enemy stats, giving you greater rewards. Win for new players and veterans alike. As you progress through the game you gain new units fairly steadily. Completing all adventures in a kingdom unlocks that kingdom's epic troop and keys\gems are gained from time to time that allow you more troops.\nThe game is fun and strategic, I love making new armies to find various combinations of troops and even order in the army is important. Great game with always more to gain. Sometimes I've got a half hour and get a couple games in, sometimes I sit for hours at a time and grind out souls, gold or other achievments. Highly recomended.

reviewText: I'm not going to post a comprehensive review, but I did want to say that this is one of the better match-3 games out there, and as a MMO-style game, it's the best match-3 I've seen.  I finished Puzzle Quest 1 & 2, and Puzzle Quest Galactrix on the DS back in the day (yes, match-3 games are my guilty pleasure), and so far this game is at least as fair in AI as those games were.  Unless something changes, I don't think anyone needs to worry about the AI stacking on you just to make you buy things.  That said, the game does get progressively harder.  Each area starts out relatively easy, then as you progress you eventually start losing.  At that point, just move to the next area, earn some more goodies, get more powerful, and then come back later and kick butt.\n\nRating this game within its genre, I would give it a 5/5 today.  That said, it's lacking in a big way in that it doesn't have guild chat you can use during games.  Really, the match-3 aspect only goes so far so they could really make this much more social than we've seen in this genre in the past.

reviewText:
For me this is definitely the best puzzle game since Puzzle Quest, as it is similar in a lot of ways but definitely more interesting for me.

I can understand the frustration of some people here, but those frustrations are in my opinion avoided rather easily. For anyone interested in this game, I'd definitely recommend reading up about it first before playing. If you spend your gold on the wrong things (i.e. keys), you'll probably feel like there is a paywall pretty soon. Instead, when you can, play the Arena to earn nice sums of gold, keys and other stuff. Just read up about what monsters work well there and you should be able to consistently win and at least break even every time.

There's a lot of different monsters to play with and other interesting mechanics, so it stays interesting for quite a while. Sure, sometimes you'll lose out of bad luck, but there's a lot of different skills with very varied mechanics and it definitely influences how the game will go.

reviewText: My husband introduced me to this on XBox One. It's just as addictive as Bejeweled. In fact, it's like a cross between Bejeweled and Magic: The Gathering. All of the puzzles are in versus mode, so you have to be careful about setting up shots for your opponent. (I can be terrible about that.) You can level all of your cards/characters up as you see fit, though. There is a quest/storyline, but you get to choose which kingdoms to unlock. Completing all challenges and other requirements will level up a kingdom as well, though I haven't seen how that plays a part in things yet.\n\nFair warning, this game does have the option to buy things with real money. It's fairly minimal compared to most games, thankfully. While you can buy useful items and packages, it's not full of micro-transactions like Candy Crush or Frozen.

reviewText:
Enjoyable, challenging, and good at what it is just like the Other Puzzle Quest series. The one gripe I had about this game is at the beginning where you start with low cash, and need to fight. Because in order to fight you have to spend 50+ gold to fight, and when you win, you get like 5-40 gold back, depends on how well you did in the fight. So your cash reserves will slowly deplete. First day you can easily run out of cash, however if you keep logging in and get the daily bonus, and join a guild you will have sufficient cash flow to last the day.

Pros:
Fun, entertaining
Huge amount of troops for endless combo's
PvP
Never have to spend a single penny to be viable or to enjoy the game.

Cons:
Story to the quests is like reading a 10 page 1st grade book with 2 sentences a page. Also feels like it was written by a first grader.
Initial difficulty to generate a cashflow
PvP(I know its in pros, but here is the con side) PvP is inactive, meaning you don't have to be online to be attacked, and when you attack someone they aren't online. The downside of this is I have lost multiple PvP fights only to take revenge on them and be extremely baffled as to how the AI made me lose, it's almost impossible to lose with the troop setup I have to some of these people, yet I do.

reviewText:
Hard for me to not reccomend this game, but it has a 3 very serious issues that set it back from being a wonderful game.

Firstly, the energy system is completely and fundamentally broken. Basically, it costs you gold to play missions, whether you win or loose. That would be bad enough, except you usually don't even get a net positive in gold when you win a mission. That's right, it costs you more to play and win than it would to not play. There is this tax system kinda thing with the kingdoms that lets you get more eventually, but when taken into account that you're suppose to be buying new units and unlocking new kingdoms with this same currency, it's difficult to even get enough to play, and keep in mind, this is the basic currency, not the premium currency. I really can't think of why they would do this either, as nobody in the world is going to buy the currency for IRL cash, since you need it so often and in such bulk, and that there's really no way to make a net positive. Which keep in mind, breaking even is simply being able to keep playing the game.

Secondly, The AI cheats. No, i'm not just bad at the game, to give you some backround, the game plays like a combat trun-based bejeweled, 4 in a ro or an alligning row of 3 gives you a free turn, and lining up attack tile or collecting enough of one color ball will fill up an energy bar you can use for abilities. If you get 4 or 5 in a row, or two connected rows of 3, you get a free turn before your opponent can do anything. The AI will regularly get 4+ tiles in a row 4+ times in a row. This leaves you just frustrated watching it get stupidly lucky while you're helpless to do anything but watch, just hoping it will be done at some point. This is especially frustrating when considering the jumbled mess of a currency system, and that when you loose, you loose the money you put in just to fight.

Finally, and this one is only really an issue in light of the other problems, it wouldn't be that bad if it weren't for the energy system, but there's no way to really grind missions. Every time you beat a level, from what i can tell, there's no way to do taht level again. This means you're going to be going up against a lot of things you might not be ready for, and with the energy system, it's pretty much a hole you can't dig yourself out of.

If at some point these issues get resolved, the game will be great! Apart from those issues it's quite fun and if they'd just fix these glaring problems, i'd reccomend it to anyone in a heartbeat.

Edit: march 10 2016

All these issues have been fixed! Which is great. There is the problem now that it's impossible to get above green cards with gold now, whereas before you could get legendary cards, but overall it's an improvement, and i think the game is worth reccomending now. Still, it would be better if they could include at least a small chance of getting at least blue rarity cards, or have some way of getting rarer cards with regular income.

reviewText:
I'm mostly torn about this game, because it is incredibly well polished and you can tell that a lot of care went into the art, mechanics, card variety, mini-economy, etc. But at the same time, it feels kind of shallow and unrewarding. The Match 3 aspect is very rudimentary, and doing it well or doing it poorly isn't really rewarded or punished all that much except at the highest level of PvP play, which makes it kind of a vestigial add-on to the overall gameplay.

That said, the game is full of sweet art, neat monster ideas, and a pretty rewarding progression ladder that never really makes you feel like you're stuck anywhere waiting for the next big drop to happen. The larger meta game of card collection/organization and building the perfect army seems well done, but just wasn't compelling enough for me to get really invested in when the underlying match 3 mechanic seems a bit lacking. It'd almost save effort if you just clicked a button to roll a die or pull a lever.

If you like games with lots of stuff then this could be a game for you, since you are constantly collecting ephermera and mcguffins to cash in to improve your character, your army, or just cosmetics. In the end though that wasn't really enough for me. I will mark it as a recco though simply through the remarkable effort that went into its making, especially for a F2P title.

reviewText: Devs are trying to make it better
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
New Review, Post Major patch.

(Previous review tl;dr - Avoid.)

So. The devs actually acted on a few things, which surprised the hell out of me. They removed gold as a barrier from attacking, questing, and generally playing the game. That's a great start. It means you can now play the game as often as you wish, which was my major gripe pre-patch.

they also added a crafting section which is nice, added lots more things to purchase with gold, glory and gems (i've got mixed issues with that, but i'll get to it below), and streamlined the interface somewhat.

I've switched my review to positive, since the barrier to actually playing is gone, so for a casual game, it's both free and playable at your own pace. Don't get me wrong - there are still flaws, and some of them are major. But not enough to keep me from playing for months at this point.

Right. Flaws. The random nature of drops mean you may literally never get cards you are missing. And since crafting is dependant (for part of it anyhow) on getting multiple cards, or specific ingredients to upgrade cards, well, it can be a pain in the posterior to get stronger.

The matchmaking system is possibly the weakest part of the entire game. I have no idea why, but you wind up with at least half your matches against opponents that vastly outlevel you. Or outpower you. Having said that, it's obvious in more cases than one that some of these opponents are paying their way to power, which is, again, a real flaw in the game for me.

They also introduced maps and arena options, but maps are boring beyond belief for, well, terrible rewards. Perhaps if they allowed you to craft multiple maps into a single more powerful map, people would start using them. As it stands, i've got several hundred of the things gathering dust. Arena is equally unsatisfying, essentially because you get better rewards (read:gold) from pvp fights.

There's lots more to say, but by now you have either installed it and are trying it, or have moved on, and so be it.

Kudos to the dev's for listening to the community and making more positive changes than negative.

Updated March 4, 2016.

reviewText:
Patch 1.09 update: Heroes are buffed, treasure maps are more rewarding along with two new kingdoms + other goodies!

I love the frequent content updates.



Edit:  Woo free costs for battles now!

I have followed this game and it's changes since the beginning and there has been frequent content updates and the game keeps getting better and better.  The beginning is very rough as all matches cost gold, but it smooths out after the first initial days. I end up making more gold per game than the cost. For beginners without the troops, it might be more efficient to do the arena minigame where you get 3 random troops.  For people wanting a bigger challenge, the difficulty can be ramped up.
I have fun coming up with new troop combinations. Common troops can be as usefull as the legendary ones.

It's also possible to get the money gems in game. Overall, a very fair F2P game.

reviewText: I initially enjoyed this game quite a bit. It a match 3 combat game, like Puzzle Quest. The game plays smoothly, though the AI is not very good. The game has some RPG elements in which you acquire troops, level them up, and build your attack force before each match. It's fairly addictive, and I had fun with the game for a while. The troop management interface needs to be improved - browsing your troop's abilities is frustrating (an Xbox or Playstation constrained interface?) and there's no easy way to compare troops or compare your current army with alternatives. But the ability to build your army and attack other player's armies (the PvP part of the game) is fun and so I enjoyed this game for a while.\n\nHowever, the real annoyance of the game comes after you have played a bit and start encountering armies that have troop lineups far better than you will ever obtain. I started encountering troops tougher than any I've ever obtained (able to wipe me out quickly). The problem is that you have to obtain keys to unlock chests that contain three random troops, with most troops obtained this way common" and not very strong - very collecticle card game-like. The good troops are rare
date: so you can only get them by getting a lot of keys. Yet keys are also uncommon unless you spend a lot of real money.  You can't even grind for keys because every match costs you in-game gold and gold is earned on a fairly slow timer (you earn some as rewards for winning
recommended: but you earn less than it costs to play matches). Once I started encountering enemy armies full of epic troops I was toast because I'm not finding epic troops for my army. The real-money costs to buy gold or keys are stupidly high - if you want to play more than a small bit per day you'll need pay more for this game than for a premium game. Some nights I'd be playing well for an hour and then
voteText: I'm out of in-game gold.\n\nSo

reviewText:
The game has been patched, let's rejoy and àplay it together again! ^_^

_____________________

Old review:

In this state, I just cannot in good conscience recommend this game. The concept is fun, they add a ton of new content regularly (new kingdoms / troops / weapons / game modes...). They also hold sales regularly to incite people to spend money, which is understandable.
BUT there is a major problem: they just don't fix bugs. Some have been going on since the Steam release and have NEVER been patched. Which makes the game infuriating, and sometimes downright unplayable (such as the AI getting free extra turns for no reason whatsoever, the worst offender bug of them all in my opinion, or having wins counted as losses, particularly damaging when playing the arena). Also, actual PvP is non-existent at the moment, which I believe is a shame.
So yeah, it's cool to add new content and ask people to give them money, but honestly, as long as they don't work on fixing what's broken before releasing new stuff, the game is just not worth it. Wait for them to fix the bugs before trying it out.

reviewText:
I can understand people disliking the game at first because it has a rough start. But once you get the flow of the game and understand the economy you can progress very fast. An active guild is very recommended and can get you all the gems you need to buy costumes which grant you benefits (look into the forums to find a great guild!).

It's not a pay-2-win game. I have the top two costumes and still 700 excess gems. Also have most troops, only lacking some legendarys and event troops I missed, but they will return eventually. And enough souls to level up any troops I want to try out to max.

The AI also doesn't cheat. My win rate at the moment is more than 95%. I would rather say the game can get too easy once you have a good synergetic composition of max lvl troops.

What I really like about the game are the events and the ammount of stuff you can do. You can sink a lot of time into it but it's also fine to play it for only half an hour each day. In my opinion one of the top games of it's kind and hugely underrated by people who couldn't get into the game.

reviewText:
This might be my first review. This game is pretty much the best time killer ever, especially if you loved the Puzzle Quest games. I think I might have spent 4.99 for a deal I was offered, which is probably a one time offer to give you a taste of what their shop can offer.... BUT I dont see me spending more unless its another 4.99 deal. I pretty much give all my gold to my guild tasks and it pays off and a little pvp each week gives you plenty of that curreny to buy the special items in the rewards shop.

If I can offer a couple pieces of essential advice.

1. Get in an active guild ASAP. Monitor the activity and leave if its dead.

2. Finish all the quests in the first town ASAP to unlock the arena, everytime you get 1k gold do an arena which is alot like the Hearthstone arena. You dont use your cards and you get to pick from a 3 card draw, three times. You can lose twice and win 8 times. You make your money back if you win twice but winning 8 times gives you 1500g, 2 keys, 400 souls and 10 trophies.

If you have not played Puzzle quest and liked even one match 3 try this out. Also dont forget to link your android device if you want to play it from that.

reviewText:
First of all,  I wouldn't consider this a card game, and it is unlike normal match-3 games. It is, however, some kind of blend between the two.

There are many cards to collect, but very few of each class, and you can only use 4 [and in some cases, 5] at a time. Considering that you level your cards, I would consider it more of a RPG.

About the match-3 aspect, it isn't really about just matching three, as it is very strategic and is strongly affected by luck. It is turn-based and you have infinite time.

One more aspect to consider is that in PvP, you only play against a bot. Playing with a human in real time is currently not featured.

There is much to say about this game: it has many weak points, but all in all it's a solid game and it's worth a try.

reviewText:
Call this the Counter review.   Countering a lot of the negative reviews here for 2.0.  I didn't play the previous build, so I don't have an axe to grind.  I'm not really invested in the game, so I don't care if it's different than it was before.  There are lots of reviews here from players who feel wronged by the game's changes.  Since those changes didn't impact me, I'm just going to talk about the game as it is and the experience of playing 2.0.

I played Puzzle Quest 1 and 2 a lot.  And several of the other Puzzle-type games from this and other publishers.  And while I really enjoyed the earlier titles, after awhile they just got boring.  They were slow and it was more fun to go play Diablo or something else with a little excitement to it.

So I'm very happy to report that this game is fast.  The animations are fast, the tile moves are fast, the tutorial is fast, the interface is fast.   But at the same time, you're totally in control of the speed.  If you like to spend time stratgezing before making a match, you can.  If you just like to play oh-what-thehell and make matches as fast as possible, you can.

There was a certain amount of grinding in the other games and a storyline to follow.  There is here, too, but much more rewarding and no where near as tedious.   Every match gives you something.

When the game opens, after a 3-step tutorial, you'll end up with a few important things.  Your first town, your first troop cards, your first rewards, which consist of some chest keys, some soul stones and some gold.  You can spend the gold leveling your town, which will give you more daily gold or you can spend the gold in other ways to improve your game.  The keys you use to open chests that give you more souls, cards and trait stones.   I got an epic troop card from my second chest.

I took that epic card and upgraded it with my soul stones.  I then put it on my team (not sure why they call your troops a team, but whatever).   I equipped my hero with a new weapon, added a few common troop cards I received in my other chests and started on my first town's quest.

Pretty soon I had enough gold to buy another town, which contained another quest string.  I now have four towns, each with their own separate quest string.   I received an epic troop card for completion of the first town's quest line, upgraded that and started playing PvP.

I really wish they had not named it PvP, even though it is, it isn't.  One reason I wish they had not is because a lot of players have negative views of PvP, since it often engenders a toxic community, loss is often ridiculed and the pressure to compete leads players to make ill-informed or just plain poor decisions regarding their real life money.   Another reason I wish they had not named it PvP is that you actually don't play another person.  You play against the AI, which is using the other person's team (of cards, like yours).

So, I gave it a whirl and it turned out to be no different than playing the quest line or the PvE challenges.  The game is exactly the same.  You simply get some different rewards and rank up, which gives you more rewards, gold and soul stones, to improve your game.   There's nothing horrible about it.  No one makes funny noises or calls you names.  Because there isn't anyone there.  The AI loses gracefully or wins gracefully and you move on.

Pros:

Fun graphics
Plenty of PvE
Fast gameplay
Sense of advancement
Enjoyable PvP
Classes as you level up
Troop card animations
Troop card improvements (leveling, new traits, ascend in rank)

Cons:
No cursor tooltips
No explanation of the icons of which there are a great many on cards, on character sheet, on the UI, etc., etc.

The Cash Shop:
Will give you an advantage on how fast you level, acquire gold and other in-game currency.  Whether you can parlay this into a top spot on the leaderboards depends on whether you have a good, basic strategy to begin with.

Rating:  8/10

Quite enjoyable and fast-paced.  Great way to spend a few hours.

reviewText:
Gems of War is a good (Im not going to lie, I decided download this game because it looks like Puzzle Quest).
But why?
Note: I NEVER TRIED PVP SO I WILL NOT TALK ABOUT PVP

The game is a mix of match 3 of the same color+cards. So you have your cards, one of them is your hero and the rest are monsters/soldiers/knights/goblins and many other creatures. Each card has an ability that can be used to turn tide when needed. At the beginning you dont have strong cards and you have to grind coins or cards to level them up, I like those game were you need to grind to become better.  I have played just 4 hours but so far I like the game, someday I may try the PVP but for now I will continue on PvE.

Pros:
-Lots of Cards
-Decent Story
-Good" music
-You can level up your cards
-Your Hero is a card
-Certain cards have helpful abilities (even the first ones)
-Some battles can be intense

Cons:
-Can be repetitive (for some people)
-Sometimes you need to grind (for some people)
- Some bosses are extremely annoying because of the abilities they use.

In the end Gems of War is a good Free to Play
date: no need to spend money (I dont know if in PvP). If you are looking for a game to spend some time
recommended: I recommend you download Gems of War. Also its free! so try it.\n\n8/10"
